nexttext: which combines with another quark to form the composite Weyl-fermion states,
prevtext:
\title{Diboson channels in ALTAS and CMS experiments}
\author{She-Sheng Xue}
\email{xue@icra.it}
\affiliation{ICRANeT, Piazzale della Repubblica, 10-65122, Pescara,\\
Physics Department, University of Rome ``La Sapienza'', Rome,
Italy} 





\begin{abstract}
We briefly recall the previous publications 
PLB1996,2013,2014,2015,NPB1997,2000 and PRD2000,2001 on the 
effective field theory of composite particles and their SM gauge couplings 
in the domain of UV-stable fixed point of relevant four-fermion operators, 
and on the resonant and nonresonant phenomena for experimental searches, 
in particular the final states of multijets. We then focus the discussions 
on the decay and annihilation channels of composite particles 
into the final states of the SM gauge bosons, leptons and quarks in connection 
with the on-going searches of the ATLAS and CMS experiments at energy $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV.
Composite bosons (fermions) produced by LHC $pp$-collision 
decay (annihilate) into two gauge bosons 
$\gamma\gamma$, $\gamma Z^0$, $W^+W^-$, $Z^0Z^0$ and the ratios
of decay (annihilation) rates are given. A composite fermion decays into an elementary
fermion and a composite boson, the latter being an intermediate state decays into
two gauge bosons, leading to a peculiar kinematics of final states 
of a jet and two gauge bosons. These provide the justification for
the verification or falsification of such a theoretical framework beyond the SM.        
\end{abstract}

\pacs{12.60.-i,12.60.Rc,11.30.Qc,11.30.Rd,12.15.Ff}

\maketitle


\noindent
{\bf Introduction.}
\hskip0.1cm
The parity-violating (chiral) gauge symmetries and spontaneous/explicit 
breaking of these symmetries for the hierarchy of fermion masses have 
been at the center of a conceptual elaboration that has played a major 
role in donating to mankind the beauty of the SM for 
particle physics. The Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (NJL) model \cite{njl} of 
dimension-6 four-fermion operators at high energies and its effective 
counterpart, the phenomenological model \cite{higgs} 
of the elementary Higgs boson and its Yukawa-coupling to fermions 
at low energies, provide an elegant 
and simple description for the electroweak symmetry 
breaking and intermediate gauge boson masses. After a great 
experimental effort for many years, using
data recorded at $\sqrt{s}=7, 8$ TeV experiments of $pp$-collision 
at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC),
the ATLAS \cite{ATLAS} and CMS \cite{CMS} collaborations have 
shown the first observations of a 125 GeV scalar particle in the search 
for the SM Higgs boson. This far-reaching result
begins to shed light on this most elusive and fascinating arena of fundamental particle physics. Recently, in the Run-2 of the upgraded LHC, the preliminary 
results on $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV $pp$ collision data are prepared 
by ATLAS \cite{ATLAS2016} and CMS \cite{CMS2016} to search for new (beyond the SM) 
resonant and/or 
nonresonant phenomena that might manifest themselves in the high-energy regime with
final states of diboson, dilepton, dijet and so forth. The diphoton channel shows the
trace of a new resonance at the diphoton invariant mass 
${\mathcal M}_{\gamma\gamma}\approx 750$ GeV, which however needs to be confirmed 
by increasing the integrated luminosity of $pp$ collisions in time. 

In Refs. \cite{xue2014,xue2015},
we have already presented discussions on the possible decay channels of composite bosons 
and fermions into final states of jets and leptons in the framework of effective 
four-fermion operators in high energies. In this Letter, we focus on the discussions on the possible channels of composite bosons and fermions decaying into the final states 
of two SM gauge bosons (diboson channels), and/or jets, 
in connection with the ATLAS amd CMS on going $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV experiments. 
It is shown that the diphoton channel of composite bosons decay should have 
the largest branching ratio, however other diboson channels should contribute 
to the invariant mass ${\mathcal M}$ of possible composite-boson resonance.  
Instead composite fermions decay into a quark (jet) and a composite boson, 
the latter is an intermediate state, which then decays into two photons, i.e., 
the peculiar jet-diphoton channel. The kinematic 
relation of composite boson and fermion decays is thus definitely fixed, 
so that the theoretical scenario of composite bosons and fermions can be 
verified or excluded, provided that the diphoton channel of composite boson decay and
the jet-diphoton channel of composite fermion decay can be experimentally verified.
 

\noindent
{\bf Effective four-fermion operators.}
\hskip0.1cm
The dynamics of new physics at high energies may be represented by an effective 
theory of high-dimensional operators of fermion fields, e.g., dimension-6 four-fermion
operators, preserving at least the SM gauge symmetries.  
The strong technicolor dynamics of extended gauge theories at the 
TeV scale was invoked \cite{hill1994,bhl1990a}
to have a natural scheme incorporating the 
relevant four-fermion operator 
$G(\bar\psi^{ia}_Lt_{Ra})(\bar t^b_{R}\psi_{Lib})$ of 
the $\langle\bar t t\rangle$-condensate BHL model \cite{bhl1990}. 
On the other hand, these relevant operators can be constructed 
on the basis of phenomenology of the SM at low-energies.  
In 1989, several authors \cite{bhl1990,nambu1989,Marciano1989} 
suggested that the SM symmetry breakdown could be 
a dynamical mechanism of the NJL type that 
intimately involves the top quark at the high-energy scale $\Lambda$. 
Since then, many models based on this idea have been 
studied \cite{DSB_review}. The low-energy SM physics
was supposed to be achieved by the renormalization group (RG) 
equations in the IR-domain 
of the infrared stable (IR) stable fixed point 
with $v\approx 239.5$ GeV \cite{bhl1990a,Marciano1989,bhl1990}. 

On the other hand, a well-defined quantum field theory for the SM Lagrangian 
requires a natural 
regularization (cutoff $\Lambda$) fully preserving the SM chiral-gauge 
symmetry. The quantum gravity provides a such regularization of discrete 
space-time with the minimal length $\tilde a\approx 1.2\,a_{\rm pl}$ \cite{xue2010}, 
where the Planck length 
$a_{\rm pl}\sim 10^{-33}\,$cm. 
However, the no-go theorem \cite{nn1981} tells us 
that there is no any consistent way to regularize 
the SM bilinear fermion Lagrangian to exactly preserve the SM chiral-gauge symmetry. 
This implies that the natural quantum-gravity regularization for the SM 
leads us to consider at least four-fermion operators. 
Actually, in the torsion-free Einstein-Cartan (EC) theory of gravitational 
tetrad field $e_\mu (x)$
and spin-connection field $\omega_\mu(x)$, four-fermion operators are naturally
obtained by integrating over ``static'' torsion fields,  
\begin{eqnarray}
{\mathcal L}_{EC}(e,\omega,\psi)&=&  {\mathcal L}_{EC}(e,\omega) + 
\bar\psi e^\mu {\mathcal D}_\mu\psi +GJ^dJ_d,
\label{ec0}
\end{eqnarray}
where the axial current $J^d=\bar\psi\gamma^d\gamma^5\psi$ of massless fermion fields. 
If intermediate torsion fields propagate short distances 
$\tilde \ell \gtrsim \tilde a$ characterized by their large masses 
$\Lambda\propto \tilde \ell^{-1}$, this implies the four-fermion 
coupling $G\propto \Lambda^{-2}(\tilde a)$ and there are high-dimensional 
fermion operators for $d>6$. The relation $G\propto \Lambda^{-2}(\tilde a)$ 
should be determined by the Wilson-Kadanoff renormalization group 
approach at a nontrivial fixed point. Here we adopt the effective four-fermion 
operators (\ref{ec0}) in the context of a well-defined quantum field theory 
at the high-energy scale $\Lambda$.

In the context of the SM fermion content and gauge symmetries, 
considering massless left- and right-handed Dirac fermions $\psi_{_L}$ 
and $\psi_{_R}$ carrying the SM quantum numbers, as well as
right-handed Dirac sterile neutrinos 
$\nu_{_R}$ and their Majorana counterparts 
$\nu^{\, c}_{_R}=i\gamma_2(\nu_{_R})^*$, we obtain

\begin{eqnarray}
{\mathcal L}
&=&{\mathcal L}_{EC}(e,\omega)+\bar\psi_{_{L,R}} e^\mu {\mathcal D}_\mu\psi_{_{L,R}} 
+ \bar\nu^{ c}_{_{R}} e^\mu {\mathcal D}_\mu\nu^{ c}_{_{R}}\nonumber\\
&+&G\left(J^\mu_{_{L}}J_{_{L,\mu}} + J^\mu_{_{R}}J_{_{R,\mu}} 
+ 2 J^\mu_{_{L}}J_{_{R,\mu}}\right)\nonumber\\
&+&G\left(j^\mu_{_{L}}j_{_{L,\mu}} + 2J^\mu_{_L}j_{_{L,\mu}} 
+ 2 J^\mu_{_R}j_{_{L,\mu}}\right),
\label{art}
\end{eqnarray}
where the axial currents 
$J^\mu_{_{L,R}}\equiv \bar\psi_{_{L,R}}\gamma^\mu\gamma^5\psi_{_{L,R}}$ 
and $j^\mu_{_L}\equiv \bar\nu^c_{_R}\gamma^\mu\gamma^5\nu^c_{_R}$, and
the four-fermion operators can be written as 
\begin{eqnarray}
&+&(G/2)\left(J^\mu_{_{L}}J_{_{L,\mu}} + J^\mu_{_{R}}J_{_{R,\mu}} 
+ j^\mu_{_{L}}j_{_{L,\mu}} + 2J^\mu_{_L}j_{_{L,\mu}}\right)\label{art0}\\
&-&G\left(\, \bar\psi_{_L}\psi_{_R}\bar\psi_{_R} \psi_{_L}
+\, \bar\nu^c_{_R}\psi_{_R}\bar\psi_{_R} \nu^c_{_R}\right),
\label{art1}
\end{eqnarray}
by using the Fierz theorem. 
Equations (\ref{art0}) and 
(\ref{art1}) represent repulsive and attractive operators, respectively. 

Apart from what is possible new physics at the scale $\Lambda$ explaining the 
origin of these effective four-fermion operators, 
it is essential and necessary to study: (i) which dynamics of these operators 
undergo in terms of their couplings as functions of running energy 
scale $\mu$; (ii) associating to these dynamics where infrared (IR) 
or ultraviolet (UV) stable fixed point of physical couplings locates; 
(iii) in the domains (scaling regions) of these stable fixed points, 
which operators become physically relevant and renormalizable 
following RG equations, 
and other irrelevant operators are suppressed by the cutoff at least 
$\mathcal O(\Lambda^{-2})$.    


\noindent
{\bf Relevant and irrelevant four-fermion operators in the IR- and UV-domain.}
\hskip0.1cm 
In the Lagrangian (\ref{art1}) and weak coupling $G$-regime, 
the BHL operator 
$G(\bar\psi^{ia}_Lt_{Ra})(\bar t^b_{R}\psi_{Lib})$   
was shown \cite{bhl1990} to become physically relevant and 
renormalizable operators of effective dimension-4, due to 
the NJL-dynamics of spontaneous symmetry breaking, 
in the IR-domain of the IR-stable fixed point. Namely, it becomes 
the effective SM Lagrangian with {\it bilinear} top-quark mass term and 
Yukawa-coupling to the composite Higgs boson $H$, 
which obeys the RG equation approaching to
the low-energy SM physics characterized by the energy 
scale $v\approx 239.5$ GeV. As an energetically favorable solution 
for the ground state of spontaneous symmetry breaking, among four-fermion operators 
in Eq.~(\ref{art1})
the BHL operator 
is the only relevant operator in the IR-domain \cite{xue2013_1}. 
Other four-fermion operators in the Lagrangian 
(\ref{art1}), as well as repulsive four-fermion operators (\ref{art0}), 
do not undergo the spontaneous symmetry breaking and are irrelevant
dimension-6 operators, whose tree-level amplitudes of four-fermion scatterings are 
suppressed ${\mathcal O}(\Lambda^{-2})$, thus their deviations 
from the SM could not experimentally accessible today.
In addition, the top-quark and composite 
Higgs-boson masses are correctly 
obtained by solving RG equations in this IR-domain with the 
appropriate non-vanishing form-factor of the Higgs 
boson in TeV scales \cite{xue2014,xue2013}. 

In the strong coupling $G$-regime, it was shown \cite{xue1997} that 
massive composite bosons and fermions are formed 
by relevant four-fermion operators (\ref{art1})
\footnote{The repulsive four-fermion 
operators (\ref{art0}) are irrelevant operators of dimension-6, and 
thus suppressed ${\mathcal O}(\Lambda^{-2})$ for the reasons that 
they are neither associated with the dynamics 
of spontaneous symmetry breaking in the IR-domain, nor associated 
with the dynamics of forming composite particles in the UV-domain.},
leading to the phase transition from the symmetry-breaking phase 
to the symmetric phase. 
We preliminarily calculated \cite{xue2014}
the $\beta(G)$-function, $\beta(G)>0$ for the weak coupling $G$ 
and $\beta(G)<0$ for the strong coupling $G$, indicating 
the UV-domain of a UV-stable fixed point at TeV scales, 
correspondingly to the scaling region of the phase transition point. 
The effective field theory in this UV-domain is expected to 
contains relevant dimension-4 operators, the massive composite 
particle spectrum and preserves the SM chiral gauge symmetries. 

This is reminiscent of the 
asymptotic safety \cite{w1} that quantum 
field theories regularized at UV cutoff $\Lambda$ 
might have a non-trivial 
UV-stable fixed point, RG flows 
are attracted into the UV-stable fixed point  
with a finite number of physically renormalizable operators. 
The weak and strong four-fermion coupling $G$ brings us into 
two distinct domains. 
This lets us also recall the QCD dynamics: asymptotically free quark states 
in the domain of a UV-stable fixed point
and bound hadron states in the domain of a possible IR-stable fixed point.


\noindent
{\bf SM gauge symmetric four-fermion operators.}
\hskip0.1cm
In the quark sector (\ref{art1}), the four-fermion operators read 
\begin{eqnarray}
G\left[(\bar\psi^{ia}_Lt_{Ra})(\bar t^b_{R}\psi_{Lib})
+ (\bar\psi^{ia}_Lb_{Ra})(\bar b^b_{R}\psi_{Lib})\right]+\cdot\cdot\cdot,
\label{bhlx}
\end{eqnarray}
where $a,b$ are the color indexes of the top and bottom quarks, the 
$SU_L(2)$ doublet $\psi^{ia}_L=(t^{a}_L,b^{a}_L)$ 
and singlet $\psi^{a}_R=t^{a}_R,b^{a}_R$ are the eigenstates 
of electroweak interactions. 
The first and second terms in Eq.~(\ref{bhlx}) are respectively 
the four-fermion operators of top-quark channel \cite{bhl1990} 
and bottom-quark channel,
whereas ``$\cdot\cdot\cdot$" stands for 
the first and second quark families that can be obtained 
by substituting $t\rightarrow u,c$ and $b\rightarrow d,s$. 

In the lepton sector (\ref{art1}), the four-fermion operators 
in terms of gauge eigenstates read,
\begin{eqnarray}
G\left[(\bar\ell^{i}_L\ell_{R})(\bar \ell_{R}\ell_{Li})
+ (\bar\ell^{i}_L\nu^\ell_{R})(\bar \nu^\ell_{R}\ell_{Li}) 
+ (\bar\nu^{\ell\, c}_R\nu^{\ell\,}_{R})(\bar \nu^{\ell}_{R}\nu^{\ell c}_{R})\right],
\label{bhlxl}
\end{eqnarray}
preserving all SM gauge symmetries, 
where the lepton $SU_L(2)$ doublets $\ell^i_L=(\nu^\ell_L,\ell_L)$, singlets 
$\ell_{R}$ and the conjugate fields of sterile neutrinos 
$\nu_R^{\ell c}=i\gamma_2(\nu_R^{\ell})^*$.  
Coming from the second term in Eq.~(\ref{art1}), the last term in Eq.~(\ref{bhlxl}) 
preserves the symmetry 
$U_{\rm lepton}(1)$ for the lepton-number 
conservation, although $(\bar \nu^{\ell}_{R}\nu^{\ell c}_{R})$ 
violates the lepton number of family ``$\ell$'' by two units. 
Similarly, there are following four-fermion operators
\begin{eqnarray}
G\left[(\bar\nu^{\ell\, c}_R\ell_{R})(\bar \ell_{R}\nu^{\ell\, c}_{R})
+(\bar\nu^{\ell\, c}_R u^{\ell}_{a,R})(\bar u^{\ell}_{a,R}\nu^{\ell c}_{R})
+(\bar\nu^{\ell\,c}_R d^\ell_{a,R})(\bar d^{\ell}_{a,R}\nu^{\ell c}_{R})\right],
\label{bhlbv}
\end{eqnarray}
where quark fields $u^{\ell}_{a,R}=(u,c,t)_{a,R}$ and $d^{\ell}_{a,R}=(d,s,b)_{a,R}$.

There are the SM gauge-symmetric four-fermion 
operators of quark-lepton interactions \cite{xue1999nu}, 
\begin{eqnarray}
G\left[(\bar\ell^{i}_Le_{R})(\bar d^a_{R}\psi_{Lia})
+(\bar\ell^{i}_L\nu^e_{R})(\bar u^a_{R}\psi_{Lia})\right] +\cdot\cdot\cdot,
\label{bhlql}
\end{eqnarray}
where $\ell^i_L=(\nu^e_L,e_L)$ and $\psi_{Lia}=(u_{La},d_{La})$
for the first family. The ``$\cdot\cdot\cdot$'' represents   
for the second and third families with substitutions: 
$e\rightarrow \mu, \tau$, $\nu^e\rightarrow \nu^\mu, \nu^\tau$, and 
$u\rightarrow c, t$ and $d\rightarrow s, b$. These operators are not present in the 
Lagrangian (\ref{art1}).

It is necessary to study how four-fermion operators are generated in the 
framework of the $SU(5)$ or $SO(10)$ unification theory, see Refs.~\cite{lq1997}.


\noindent
{\bf Composite particles in the UV-domain.}
\hskip0.1cm 
We turn to discuss the composite particle spectra and interacting 
vertexes in the UV-domain of the characteristic energy at TeV scale.
For the $u$-quark channel, 
the massive composite boson is an $SU_L(2)$-doublet

nexttext:
and the massive composite Dirac fermions: $SU_L(2)$ doublet 
${\bf\Psi}^{ib}_D$ and singlet ${\bf\Psi}^{b}_D$,
prevtext: which combines with another quark to form the composite Weyl-fermion states,

nexttext:
where the form-factors $Z^{^S}_{R,L}$ and $[Z^{^S}_\Pi]^{1/2}$ are 
generalized wave-function renormalization of composite fermion and boson operators. 
These composite particles have the SM-gauge symmetric masses
\begin{eqnarray}
M^2_\Pi{\mathcal A}^{i}{\mathcal A}^{i\dagger},\quad
M_F\bar{\bf\Psi}^{ib}_D{\bf\Psi}^{ib}_D,\quad {\rm and}\quad 
M_F\bar{\bf\Psi}^{b}_D{\bf\Psi}^{b}_D.
\label{boundm}
\end{eqnarray}  
For the $d$-quark channel, the composite particles are represented by 
Eq.~(\ref{bound}) 
with the replacement $u_{Ra}\rightarrow d_{Ra}$, carrying the 
different quantum numbers of the $U_Y(1)$ gauge group. 
The same discussions also apply for the second and third quark families 
by substituting the $SU_L(2)$ doublet $(u_{La}, d_{La})$ 
into $(c_{La}, s_{La})$ or $(t_{La}, b_{La})$  and singlet 
$u_{Ra}$  into $t_{Ra}$ or $c_{Ra}$, as well as singlet 
$d_{Ra}$  into $b_{Ra}$ or $s_{Ra}$. 

In the lepton sector, the composite boson and Weyl-fermion states formed by the first 
term ($\ell_R$-channel) of Eq.~(\ref{bhlxl}) are:
\begin{eqnarray}
{\mathcal A}^i=[Z^{^S}_H]^{1/2}(\bar\ell_{R} \ell^{i}_L);
\qquad {\bf\Psi}^{i}_R=Z^{^S}_R{\mathcal A}^i\ell_{R}\,,
\quad {\bf\Psi}_{L}=Z^{^S}_L{\mathcal A}^{i\dagger}\ell_{iL},
\label{boundl}
\end{eqnarray}
and the massive composite Dirac fermions ${\bf\Psi}^{i}_D=(\ell^{i}_L, {\bf\Psi}^{i}_R)$ 
and ${\bf\Psi}_D=({\bf\Psi}_{L},\ell_R)$. Compared with their counterparts 
(\ref{boundb}-\ref{boundd}) in the quark sector, 
these massive composite particles have different 
quantum numbers of the SM gauge symmetries. 
The composite particles formed by the second 
term ($\nu^\ell_R$-channel) of Eq.~(\ref{bhlxl}) are obtained by the 
replacement $\ell_R\rightarrow \nu^\ell_R$, and they carry no charge 
of the $U_Y(1)$ gauge group. 
 
Analogously, we present for the $e_R$-channel of quark-lepton 
interactions (\ref{bhlql}), 
the massive composite Dirac fermions: $SU_L(2)
$ doublet ${\bf\Psi}^{i}_D=(\ell^{i}_L, {\bf\Psi}^{i}_R)$ and singlet 
${\bf\Psi}_D=({\bf\Psi}_{L},e_R)$, where the renormalized composite boson and 
three-fermion states are:

and the massive composite Dirac fermions: $SU_L(2)$ doublet 
${\bf\Psi}^{ib}_D$ and singlet ${\bf\Psi}^{b}_D$,

For the $\nu^{\,e}_R$-channel, the composite particles are represented 
by Eq.~(\ref{boundem}) with the replacements 
$e_{R}\rightarrow \nu^{\,e}_{R}$ and $d^{\,a}_{R}\rightarrow u^{\,a}_{R}$,

where the form-factors $Z^{^S}_{R,L}$ and $[Z^{^S}_\Pi]^{1/2}$ are 
generalized wave-function renormalization of composite fermion and boson operators. 
These composite particles have the SM-gauge symmetric masses
\begin{eqnarray}
M^2_\Pi{\mathcal A}^{i}{\mathcal A}^{i\dagger},\quad
M_F\bar{\bf\Psi}^{ib}_D{\bf\Psi}^{ib}_D,\quad {\rm and}\quad

{\mathcal A}^i=[Z^{^S}_H]^{1/2}(\bar\ell_{R} \ell^{i}_L);

these massive composite particles have different

$ doublet ${\bf\Psi}^{i}_D=(\ell^{i}_L, {\bf\Psi}^{i}_R)$ and singlet 
${\bf\Psi}_D=({\bf\Psi}_{L},e_R)$, where the renormalized composite boson and

}
carrying
different quantum numbers of the $U_Y(1)$ gauge group. 
The composite particles from the second and third families 
can be obtained by substitutions: 
$e\rightarrow \mu, \tau$, $\nu^e\rightarrow \nu^\mu, \nu^\tau$, and 
$u\rightarrow c, t$ and $d\rightarrow s, b$. 
 
These composite particles are composed only by the SM elementary particles, and 
there are no extra elementary gauge bosons and fermions, 
except the right-handed sterile neutrino $\nu_R$.
The propagators of these composite particles have 
poles and residues that respectively 
represent their masses and form-factors \cite{xue1997}.  
As long as their form-factors are finite, 
these composite particles behave as elementary particles. 
Compared with the SM in the IR-domain of the symmetry breaking phase, 
massive composite particles in the UV-domain 
of the symmetric phase have the same quantum numbers 
of SM chiral gauge symmetries $SU_c(3)\times SU_L(2)\times U_Y(1)$, couplings 
$g_1,g_2,g_3$ 
to SM gauge bosons $\gamma,W^\pm, Z^0$ and gluon, 
but the massive spectrum and interacting vertex are 
vector-like fully preserving the parity-symmetry. 
Composite Dirac fermion $\Psi_D$ carries 
an electric charge $q=(2/3,-1/3,-1,0)$.

The gauge symmetric masses $M_{\Pi,F}$ and form factors $Z^S_{\Pi,L,R}$ 
of composite particles, e.g., (\ref{boundb}-\ref{boundm}) can be different 
from one to another, due to the family mixing and/or some other effects that
we do not consider here. When their form-factors vanish, these 
composite particles dissolve (decay) to their constitutes 
of SM elementary particles as final states. In the following, 
we discuss the decay and annihilation channels of these composite particles 
into the SM elementary particles, in particular two gauge bosons, as final states.



\noindent{\bf Composite bosons decay.}
\hskip0.1cm 
For the sake of simplicity, we 
adopt the first quark family $\psi^i_L=(u,d)_L$ and $\psi_R=u_R,d_L$ for illustrations, and 
the discussions can be 
generalized to other families including leptons. 
The $SU_L(2)$-charged composite boson ${\mathcal A}^i\equiv (\bar u_R\psi^i_L)$
or ${\mathcal A}^i\equiv (\bar d_R\psi^i_L)$
and its SM-gauge invariant mass term $M_\Pi^2 {\mathcal A}^i{\mathcal A}^{i\dagger}$ 
(\ref{boundm}). The complex scalar field ${\mathcal A}^i$ has four components 
$A^i_\pm=({\mathcal A}^i\pm {\mathcal A}^{i\dagger})/2$, 
\begin{eqnarray}
A_+^1&=&\bar uu,\quad A_+^2 =\bar ud\,; \quad 
\quad A_-^1=\bar u\gamma_5u, 



\quad A_-^2=\bar u\gamma_5d 
\label{4comp}
\end{eqnarray} 
and $u\longleftrightarrow d$ for ${\mathcal A}^i\equiv (\bar u_R\psi^i_L)
\rightarrow {\mathcal A}^i\equiv (\bar d_R\psi^i_L)$. 

In Eq.~(\ref{4comp}), the pseudo-scalars form 
composite meson states $\Pi^0$ and $\Pi^\pm$ carry the same quantum numbers of pions
$\pi^0$ and $\pi^\pm$ in the SM, however different masses $M_{\Pi^{0,\pm}}\gg m_{\pi^{0,\pm}}$. 
Apart from the different kinematic threshold, 
these composite mesons undergo all decay channels of pions. Here we only discuss 
the channels expected to be largest branching ratio and energetically favorable,
\begin{eqnarray}
\Pi^0&\rightarrow &\gamma \gamma, \gamma Z^0, W^+W^-, Z^0Z^0, \label{pidecay}\\ 
\Pi^+&\rightarrow& 
t + b, \cdot\cdot\cdot ; \tau^+ + \nu_\tau,
\cdot\cdot\cdot,
\label{pidecay+}
\end{eqnarray} 
and their charged conjugated channels. In the Feynman diagram representation, 
these are the triangles of 
quark loops with three interaction vertexes, one associates to the axial current 
of $\Pi^0$ and other two are electroweak interactions associate to the SM gauge bosons. 
In the rest frame of composite meson $\Pi^{0\pm}$, 
the final states of two body decay follow the energy-momentum conservations 
${\bf p}_{1}=-{\bf p}_{2}, |{\bf p}_{1}|=|{\bf p}_{2}|$ 
and have the invariant mass ${\mathcal M}_{\rm inv}=M_{\Pi^{0,\pm}}$. 
Due to the electric Coulomb energy, $M_{\Pi^{\pm}}\gtrsim M_{\Pi^{0}}$.  
Their decay rates are expected to be the same as pions decay rates, replacing 
the mass $m_{\pi^{0,\pm}}\rightarrow M_{\Pi^{0,\pm}}$ and the decay 
constant $f_\pi\rightarrow f_\Pi$, in the neutral channel we have, 
\begin{eqnarray}
\Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow \gamma\gamma} &\approx &\left(\frac{\alpha N_c}{3\pi f_\Pi}\right)^2
\frac{M^3_{\Pi^0}}{64\pi},\quad \Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow \gamma Z^0}, 
\quad \Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow W^+W^-},\quad\Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow Z^0Z^0},
\label{0pidecayr}
\end{eqnarray}
where 
$\alpha ~(G_F)$ 
is the fine-structure (Fermi) constant. The diphoton channel (\ref{0pidecayr}) 
is expected to have the largest branching ratio. Suppose that this channel 
(\ref{0pidecayr}) might be a candidate for the possible resonance 
of the diphoton channel of the invariant mass 
${\mathcal M}_{\gamma\gamma}\approx 750$ GeV that the ATLAS and CMS
experiments are searching for. It implies that the composite meson mass 
$M_{\Pi^{0}}\gtrsim {\mathcal M}_{\gamma\gamma} \approx 750$ GeV, since there are other decay channels into
two gauge bosons of $\gamma Z^0$, $W^+W^-$ and $Z^0Z^0$. The channel 
$\gamma Z^0$ corresponds to the final states of a photon and two leptons or 
a ``fat'' jet of two quarks. The channels 
$W^+W^-$ and $Z^0Z^0$ correspond to the final states of (i) 
two ``fat'' jets of four quarks for $W$ and $Z$ hadronical decays or 
(ii) four leptons for $W$ and $Z$ leptonical decay, or a ``fat'' jet 
and two leptons in the combination of cases (i) and (ii). 
Due to $M_{\Pi^{0}}\gg M_{W,Z}$, the $W$ and $Z$ bosons
are approximately ``massless'', and the rates of these channels 
are approximately given by Eq. (\ref{0pidecayr}) with proper gauge couplings of the SM.
Using the $W^\pm$-coupling $g_2/(2\sqrt{2})=e/(2\sqrt{2} \sin\theta_W)$ and the 
$Z^0$-coupling $\approx g_2/(4\cos\theta_w)$ to fermion fields, 
we can approximately estimate the decay-rate ratios 
\begin{eqnarray}
\Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow \gamma Z^0} /\Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow \gamma\gamma}&\approx & 
(16\sin^2\theta_W \cos^2\theta_W)^{-1}\approx 1/2.8,\nonumber\\
\Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow W^+W^-} /\Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow \gamma\gamma}&\approx & 
(8\sin^2\theta_W)^{-2}\approx 1/3.4,\nonumber\\
\Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow Z^0 Z^0} /\Gamma_{\Pi^0\rightarrow \gamma\gamma}&\approx & 
(16\sin^2\theta_W \cos^2\theta_W)^{-2}\approx 1/8.0,
\label{br}
\end{eqnarray} 
where $\theta_W$ is the Weinberg angle and $\sin^2\theta_W\approx 0.23$. These relations provide 
the verification or falsification of the composite particle scenario, 
if the resonance of diphoton channel is confirmed and 
other diboson channels are also observed and measured.  
It is also possible that the composite meson 
$\Pi^0$ decays into the dijet final state of 
two quarks which was already discussed in Ref.~\cite{xue2014,xue2015}. 
Suppose that 
the neutral composite meson $\Pi^0$ is produced by $pp$ collisions 
at the LHC, its resonance location ${\mathcal M}_{\rm all~ channels}=M_{\Pi^0}$, 
and the rate of each decay channel depends on
the values of the mass $M_{\Pi^0}$, decay constant $f_{_\Pi}$ 
and gauge couplings.  

In the charged channels of final states of leptons or quarks, we have 
\begin{eqnarray}
\Gamma_{\Pi^+\rightarrow \tau^++\nu_\tau
} &\approx &\frac{G_F^2}{4\pi}f^2_\Pi m_{\tau}^2
M_{\Pi^+} 
,\quad \cdot\cdot\cdot ,
\label{pidecayr1}\\
\Gamma_{\Pi^+\rightarrow t+b 
} &\approx &\frac{G_F^2}{4\pi}f^2_\Pi m_{t}^2 M_{\Pi^+}, 
\quad \cdot\cdot\cdot,
\label{pidecayr}
\end{eqnarray}
The charged quark channel (\ref{pidecayr}) is favorable because of heavy quark mass.
Suppose that the charged composite meson $\Pi^\pm$ is produced by $pp$ collisions 
at the LHC, its resonance location at the invariant mass
${\mathcal M}_{\rm qq}\approx M_{\Pi^\pm}$ of the dijet final state 
or other possible final states produced by two quarks. 
Whereas the charged lepton channel 
(\ref{pidecayr1}) implies the final state of $\tau^\pm$ lepton of
energy $\sim M_{\Pi^{\pm}}/2$ and missing energy carried away by $\nu_\tau$-neutrino.
The decay channels of dijet and dilepton were discussed in Refs.~\cite{xue2014,xue2015}. 






In Eq.~(\ref{4comp}), the scalars form composite 
quarkonium states $\bar uu$ and $\bar dd$, carrying the same quantum numbers 
of QCD quarknium states, however larger masses $\sim M_{\Pi^{0}}$. 
Apart from different kinematic threshold, 
these composite quarkonium states 
in principle undergo all decay channels of QCD quarkonium states. The discussions
are similar to the composite meson states $\Pi^{0,\pm}$, 
and will be presented in a lengthy article.   
Recall that composite meson and quarkonium states 
directly decays into dijets or dilepton without an intermediate 

state were discussed \cite{xue2014,xue2015}.  
On the basis of the SM chiral gauge symmetries and 
vector-like composite fermion 
content, there are also other possible final decay channels, analogously to those 
studied in the effective theory of QCD at low energies. Which channel 
is more relevant for detections, depending not only on its theoretical 
branching ratio in principle, 
but also on its experimental measurement in practice.              



\noindent{\bf Composite fermions decay.}
\hskip0.1cm 
For the sake of simplicity, we 
adopt the first quark family (\ref{boundb}-\ref{boundd}) to
discuss the decay of composite Dirac fermions, and 
discussions can be generalized to other families including leptons. 
The composite Dirac fermions $\Psi_D$ (\ref{boundd}) are more massive than their bosonic constituents ${\mathcal A}^i$ (\ref{boundb}), i.e., $M_F > M^{0,\pm}_\Pi$. 
They decay to the SM particles via the intermediate composite-boson states $\Pi^0$ 
(neutral decay channel) or $\Pi^\pm$ (charged decay channel) or quarkonium states. 
Suppose that at the present energy of $pp$-collision at the LHC, composite 
Dirac fermions produced are non-relativistic particles, and we consider 
them to be approximately at rest in the CM frame of $pp$ collisions. 
The neutral decay channels are 
\begin{eqnarray}
\Psi_D \rightarrow \Pi^{0} +  [\bar u_L,u_R] \rightarrow (\gamma \gamma, \gamma Z^0, W^+W^-, 
Z^0Z^0) + {\rm a~ jet},
\label{fdecay}
\end{eqnarray}
and $u\rightarrow d$. This indicates that a composite Dirac fermion $\Psi_D$ decays
into a composite meson $\Pi^0$ and a fundamental Dirac fermion, $u$-quark $[\bar u_L,u_R]$ 
or $d$-quark. The latter is an ultra-relativistic quark, $E_f\approx |{\bf p}_f|$, 
ending as a jet in the final states. And the former
is a composite meson, $E_{_{\Pi^0}}=({\bf p}_{_{\Pi^0}}^2+M_{_{\Pi^0}}^2)^{1/2}$, appearing 
as an intermediate and metastable state for 
a short time $\sim 1/M_{_{\Pi^0}}$ then decays into two photons (\ref{pidecay}) of the
energy $E_\gamma=|{\bf p}_\gamma|$ or other diboson channels. 
In the CM frame of the $pp$ collision, the composite fermion at rest decays into a quark (jet)
and a composite meson moving apart in opposite directions (${\bf p}_{_f}=-{\bf p}_{_{\Pi^0}}$). 
The kinematic distribution of final states is described by the invariant mass 
${\mathcal M}_{\rm inv}\approx M_F$, 
\begin{eqnarray}
M_F&= & E_f+ E_{_{\Pi^0}}\approx |{\bf p}_{_{\Pi^0}}| +({\bf p}_{_{\Pi^0}}^2+M_{_{\Pi^0}}^2)^{1/2}, 
\nonumber\\
|{\bf p}_{_{\Pi^0}}| &\approx & \left[|{\bf p}_{\gamma_1}|^2+|{\bf p}_{\gamma_1}|^2 + 2|{\bf p}_{\gamma_1}||{\bf p}_{\gamma_2}|\cos\theta_{\gamma_1\gamma_2}\right]^{1/2},
\label{fdecayk}
\end{eqnarray}
where $\theta_{\gamma_1\gamma_2}$ is the angle between the momenta ${\bf p}_{\gamma_1}$ and ${\bf p}_{\gamma_2}$ of two photons or other diboson states (\ref{fdecay}). 
The rate of composite fermion decay (\ref{fdecay}) should be the product 
of $\Pi_0$-decay rate (\ref{0pidecayr}) and the rate of $\Psi_D$ decaying into a quark 
and $\Pi_0$, which will be presented in a lengthy article. However, the ratios 
$(\Gamma_{\Psi_D\rightarrow \gamma Z^0+{\rm jet}}/\Gamma_{\Psi_D\rightarrow \gamma\gamma 
+{\rm jet}})$ ,
$(\Gamma_{\Psi_D\rightarrow W^+W^-+{\rm jet}}/\Gamma_{\Psi_D\rightarrow \gamma\gamma 
+{\rm jet}})$ and 
$(\Gamma_{\Psi_D\rightarrow Z^0Z^0 +{\rm jet}}/\Gamma_{\Psi_D\rightarrow \gamma\gamma +{\rm jet}})$, 
similarly to the ratios in Eq.~(\ref{br}).   

If the bosonic resonance (\ref{pidecay}) is verified and 
its invariant mass is determined, the resonance of 
composite fermion decay (\ref{fdecay})
could possibly be identified by measuring such a peculiar final-state kinematics 
(\ref{fdecayk}) of a single jet and two photons or other diboson states. 
This gives an example for the verification or falsification
of the composite boson and fermion scenario, see Eq.~(\ref{boundb}-\ref{boundd}).   
   
The charged decay channel via the intermediate meson state 
$\Pi^{\pm}$ (\ref{pidecayr}) reads
\begin{eqnarray}


\Psi_D &=&
\rightarrow \Pi^{+} +  [\bar u_L,d_R],

\label{fdecayc}
\end{eqnarray}
and its charge conjugate. The Weyl fields 
$[\bar u_L,d_R]$ do not 
form a Dirac fermion of $u$- or $d$-quark, but pick up $u_R$ and $\bar d_L$ quark from the 
vacuum, and end as 
$u$ and $d$-quark (jets) in final states. 
On the other hand, the charged composite mesons $\Pi^{\pm}$ (\ref{pidecayr}) 
most probably decay into two quarks.
Therefore, the most probable final state of composite fermion (\ref{fdecayc}) decay 
is expected to be four jets formed by four quarks, which was 
already discussed in Ref. \cite{xue2014,xue2015}.
These discussions can be generalized to the decay channels whose 
intermediate state is a quarkonium state instead of a meson state.  


\noindent{\bf Annihilation of two composite fermions.}
\hskip0.1cm             
Analogously to the annihilation of electron and positron into two photons,  
a composite Dirac fermion and its antiparticle 
annihilates to two photons, and other massive gauge bosons,  						
\begin{eqnarray}
\Psi_D+ \Psi^c_D&\rightarrow&\gamma\gamma,\gamma Z^0, W^+W^-,Z^0Z^0,\cdot\cdot\cdot
\label{anni}
\end{eqnarray}
where the composite Dirac fermion $\Psi_D$ has an electric charge $q=(2/3,-1/3,-1)$
and mass $M_F$. 
Apart from the diphoton final state,
the final states of energetic dibosons $W^+W^-$ and $Z^0Z^0$ are two ``fat'' 
jets in opposite directions, each of them is made by two energetic quarks, or 
these two bosons can decay into the final states of two lepton pairs.
While in the channel $\Psi_D+ \Psi^c_D\rightarrow \gamma Z^0$, the final states are an energetic 
photon and a ``fat'' jet or an energetic photon and a lepton pair.  

Given by the mass-energy of two 
annihilating composite Dirac fermions, 
the kinematic mass-energy of final states must be larger than $2M_F$. 
This is not an invariant energy-mass representing the resonance of an 
unstable composite particle. Suppose that massive composite Dirac fermions 
produced by the LHC $pp$-collision at present energies are non-relativistic particles,
$E_F=(|{\bf p}_F|^2+M^2_F)^{1/2}\approx M_F + |{\bf p}_F|^2/(2M_F)$, 
however their masses $M_F\sim $ TeV. Two gauge bosons 
in the final state (\ref{anni}) are ultra-relativistic,  
the cross-section $\sigma_D $ of annihilating channel (\ref{anni}) 
can be approximately estimated by the Dirac rate of point-like electron and positron 
annihilating to two photons with the replacement $m_e\rightarrow M_F$ and 
$\alpha\rightarrow q^2\alpha$, 
\begin{eqnarray}
\sigma_D \sim \pi r_0^2/v, \quad r_0=q^2\alpha/M_F, \quad  v=|{\bf p}_F|/M_F\ll 1,
\label{annicr}
\end{eqnarray}
up to the form-factors of composite Dirac fermions. 
The annihilation rate $\Gamma_D$ per unit time  
\begin{eqnarray}
\Gamma_D \approx \sigma_D v n 
\sim 2\pi r_0^2 n \sim (q^2\alpha)^2 M_F 
\label{anninon}
\end{eqnarray}
where the number density of the produced composite fermions $n\sim M_F^3/\pi$ is assumed.
We can obtain the ratios $\Gamma_{D\rightarrow \gamma Z^0}/\Gamma_{D\rightarrow \gamma\gamma}$, 
$\Gamma_{D\rightarrow W^+W^-}/\Gamma_{D\rightarrow \gamma\gamma}$ and 
$\Gamma_{D\rightarrow Z^0Z^0}/\Gamma_{D\rightarrow \gamma\gamma}$, 
similarly to the ratios in Eq.~(\ref{br}). 
Analogously to the positronium state of electron and positron pair, it is possible
that the composite fermion and its antiparticle form an intermediate 
unstable Coulomb bound state, then decaying to photons or other massive 
gauge bosons. The spin singlet of bound state decays 
into two photons (even number of photons) with the 
probability $\sim (q^2\alpha)^5 M_F$, the spin triplet of bound state
decays into three photons (odd number of photons) 
with the probability $\sim (q^2\alpha)^6 M_F$.


The following annihilation channels of two composite fermions
with different charges or zero charge are also possible, 
\begin{eqnarray}
\Psi^{-1/3}_D+ \Psi^{c2/3}_D&\rightarrow&W^-\gamma,W^- Z^0,\cdot\cdot\cdot\nonumber\\
\Psi^{0}_D+ \Psi^{0}_D&\rightarrow&W^+W^-,Z^0Z^0,\cdot\cdot\cdot
\label{anni1}
\end{eqnarray}
and their charged conjugates. 
In addition, analogously to the annihilation of electron and positron, 
through an intermediate $\gamma$-photon or $Z^0$-boson, to produce a pair of particle and antiparticle in the SM,  
a composite fermion and its antiparticle 
annihilates, through an intermediate
photon or $Z^0$-boson, and produce a pair of particle and antiparticle in the SM,  						
\begin{eqnarray}
\Psi_D+ \Psi^c_D&\rightarrow& f+ f^c,
\label{anni2}
\end{eqnarray}
where the Dirac fermion $\Psi_D$ has an electric charge $q=(2/3,-1/3,-1)$. 
The final state is an energetic lepton pair or quark pair, the former is the 
dilepton channel and the latter is the dijet channel. Similarly to the channels (\ref{anni1}) two composite Dirac fermions
with different charges or zero charge can annihilate, through an intermediate 
charged boson $W^\pm$ or neutral boson $Z^0$, to the pair of two elementary fermions in the SM. 

We skip the discussions on (i) two composite Dirac fermions annihilate to two composite bosons 
${\mathcal A}$ and ${\mathcal A}^\dagger$; (ii) the rare processes of ${\mathcal A}$ 
and ${\mathcal A}^\dagger$ annihilation and decay into gauge bosons and other particles 
through the ${\mathcal A}{\mathcal A}^\dagger\gamma$ coupling. 


 
\comment{

\section
{\bf Annihilation to two elementary fermions.}
\hskip0.1cm  
Analogously to the annihilation of an electron-positron pair, through an intermediate
$\gamma$-photon or $Z^0$-boson, to produce a pair of particle and antiparticle in the SM,  
the pair of a composite fermion and its antiparticle 
annihilates, through an intermediate
photon or $Z^0$-boson, to produce a pair of particle and antiparticle in the SM,  						
\begin{eqnarray}
\Psi_D+ \Psi^c_D&\rightarrow& f+ f^c,
\label{anni2}
\end{eqnarray}
where the Dirac fermion $\Psi_D$ has an electric charge $q=(2/3,-1/3,-1)$. 
The final state is an energetic lepton pair or quark pair, the former is the 
dilepton channel and the latter is the dijet channel.
Given by the energy-mass of two 
annihilating composite fermions, 
the kinematic energy-mass of final states must be larger than $2M_F$. 
This is not an invariant energy-mass representing the resonance of an 
unstable composite particle. Suppose that the composite fermion and its 
antiparticle produced are non-relativistic with the mass $M_F\sim $ TeV, the 
intermediate gauge-boson momentum $s=q^2=(p_++p_-)^2\approx (2 M_F)^2$. The   
intermediate gauge bosons and fermions in the final state are 
approximately massless, we obtain the cross section 
\begin{eqnarray}
\sigma(\Psi_D+ \Psi^c_D&\rightarrow& f+ f^c)\approx \frac{4\pi (q\alpha)^2}{3s}\approx \frac{4\pi (q\alpha)^2}{3(2M_F)^2},
\label{cross2}
\end{eqnarray}
}


\noindent
{\bf Summary.}
\hskip0.1cm 
For readers' convenience, we first give a very brief review of 
effective four-fermion operators, composite particle spectra and their 
possible phenomena for experimental research, 
which were presented in previous papers. We then focus the discussions 
on the decay and annihilation channels of composite bosons and fermions 
into the final states of the SM gauge bosons, leptons and quarks, in connection 
with the on-going searches of the ATLAS and CMS experiments at energy $\sqrt{s}=13$ TeV. 
The justifications are provided for
the verification or falsification of such a theoretical framework 
of massive composite particles and SM gauge couplings 
in the UV-domain of the strong coupling 
of effective four-fermion operators.

Prof.~Hagen Kleinert for discussions on 
the IR- and UV-stable fixed points of quantum field theories.
